element_texts.text: Completed

Isaac  Milo Maine      (1851?)
Jan 14, 1850  Milo Maine, Jan. 4 1850
Reeds Ferry Merrimack
Dear Antoinette  I received your welcome letter when I reached Bangor nearly a week ago. I sat down Monday Evening, Dec. 30th, and began to write to you; when Brother EIiab came in with a letter from Milo that Brother Joseph was suddenly worse. We came up to Milo as soon as possible on Tuesday but we found him dead. He died Tuesday morning.  He was taken Saturday morning 28th with a slight difficulty of breathing, and apparent effort to throw off something from the Lungs. But it was thought only the effect of a slight cold, and he was soon easier, and remained so Sunday and part of Monday. It appeared that the Paralysis suddenly attacked the Muscles about the Lungs, and rapidly progressed until it stopped his breath. But, as himself said, "he believed he has everything prepared"   He had constantly expected a fatal termination of his disease even when he seemed to others to be improving in health. When he was taken worse, he understood it, and he said at once that it would be useless to do anything for him. On Monday night when he was seised with the final distress for breath, he merely inquired of the Physician who was present "How long will it take me?" He expressed his readiness to go, and his thankfulness that he was not left, as
Completed

he had feared he should be, until the disease should reach his brain, and the mind be weakened. In the midst of his distress, he said to those around him, "Do not cry, I shall soon be well now". When asked of his state of feeling, his answer was "Perfect trust"; and said "This is indeed Joyful." "Who is he that condemneth; it is Christ that died, etc." His death was indeed joyful, triumphant the death of a Christian. Not the slightest complaint or murmur ever passed his lips, although he suffered acutely; in that respect his death was that of a storie. In his last hours as ever before he appeared thoughtful only for others, almost unconscious of himself.  His mind was perfectly clear and unclouded to the very last; and his very death seemed but the last and most perfect triumph of a pure soul and a firm and lofty intellect over the wreck? of matter, and the accidents of time.  Oh how beautiful was his corpse! It seemed, in its marble coldness, the perfect embodiment of purity and intellect. We could not weep for him: we ought rather to rejoice: Yet who that knew his worth. {Few could know half his worth}, could but weep at the untimely grave of so many hopes, of so much promise? I cannot mourn for Joseph; but I cannot get over it that I was not with him in his last hours. I finished my work at Waterville on Saturday, a week ago today. and came over to Bangor the same night, intending to remain there a few days before coming to Milo, in order to be present at a meeting of the Rail Road Company.
Completed

The Funeral was on Thursday: a Prayer at the house by the new minister here, and at the grave, the beautiful Funeral Service of the Sons of Temperance of which Society Joseph had been a leading member in Bangor.  Eliab and I returned to Bangor on Friday afternoon, but I came up here again this morning. Sister Lucy is here at Milo, came up the week before Joseph's death. Her health appears to be slowly improving. Sister Anne who came from Racine this Fall is here too, but leaves next week: is going to Westfield N.Y to take charge of the Female department of Westfield Academy. It appears probable that  the Penobscot and Kennebeck R.R Co for whom I have been at work three or four weeks will decide to go to work immediately, and that I shall be offered some kind of situation there: whether such as I shall think best to accept is uncertain, but I shall know soon.
I believe there were many things in your letter that I intend to make the subject of part at least of mine: but the letter is at Bangor, I read it but hastily at first, and do not now remember much of it. I believe I remember that you have an unpleasant and cold room.  I am afraid you have really suffered, if your room is a cold one, such extremely cold weather, as it has been for a few weeks past. The great storm last week Monday was one of the worst I ever knew, I was not out that day. but the next day was the worst day I ever worked out of doors. I did not really suffer myself, but several of my men got their ears noses or feet frostbitten, although I tried to be careful of them.  But I believe I must stop as I ought to write several letters to relatives and friends tonight. Sincerely I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Answered Jan 14.
Miss Antoinette B Putnam
Reed's Ferry Merrimack N.H.
Please be careful of this dear letter - Remember now, for I shall want it when I come home -
Completed

Isaac Milo Maine
Feb. 27, 1851
Milo Maine, Feb. 27, 1851.
Reeds Ferry NH
Dear Antoinette
Reaching here last evening I found a letter from you awaiting me, and hasten to reply to it. I have been for several weeks away from here, in fact, I could almost say, away from everywhere, making a tour through the Lumbering Region in the North and East part of this state. Your previous kind and excellent letters I received before I started and ought to have replied to at the time, but in thinking of other things I neglected or put it off at the time, and after I got into the woods there was no chance to write, though I believe I thought of it every day wherever I was. By the way I could tell you great accounts of my adventures and experiences of life in the Back woods. I went with my Brotherinlaw, Mr Furber, who is agent for large proprietors of Timber lands and is so obliged to look over the Lumbering operations occasionally, exploring the lands and surveying the lumber where it is out. I can hardly tell how long we were without sleeping in a bed or going into any house other than the Log crossed out "camps" of the Lumbermen. The sight of these camps would amuse you. The end are built of logs, the roofs go clear to the ground, and are covered with bushes, bark or boards split out logs with an axe, and the whole perhaps
Completed

two thirds covered with snow. The Chimney is merely a large hole in the middle of the roof with perhaps cogs logs built up around it like a children's Cob house. The fire inside may consist of some half a cord of wood, cut about eight feet long and burning in the middle of camp. On each side of this are laid down hemlock bought for a bed on which the men sleep in a row with their feet toward the fire. In some camps there are only six or eight men in some twenty or thirty, or even more.  We travelled from on camp to another, sometimes in the roads by which the Lumbermen carry in their supplies of provisions and hay, sometimes on the ice of the rivers and numerous lakes, and sometimes through the woods a foot on snow shoes, and guided by a pocket compass or an occasional tree blased by some previous explorer.  I really enjoyed this life in the woods considerably with its great variety now communing with those rough and hardy lumbermen, and now with the great lakes, and mountains, and waterfalls; again watching the game and the winter birds in their native home, especially the cropbills which even in the coldest weather make the sunny mornings vocal as spring around the camps; and then again apisting in counting or measuring the lumber, admiring perhaps 'fit mast for some admiral'; or perhaps for additional variety hunting or fishing a while. Grouse were abundant; we saw deer and lynxes, and moose the largest game and the largest animal of this climate, are to be found.
Completed

but though the snow was three or four feet deep, it was not hard enough then to afford a chance to hunt the moose advantageously.  On the whole I enjoyed the tour very well, at least on weekdays, but it was rather hard spending the Sabbaths in the Lumbermen's camp.  I am afraid all this account of my woods journey will not be very interesting to you.  I wish I could have been at your Exhibition at the close of last term. I should like to hear some account of it, and also of the 'visit' at Dunbarton, which it would have given me great pleasure to attend, and really quite troubled me that I could not. I do not know that I ever enjoyed any social gathering more than I did that  at your house last year. I want to hear all about it. If your vacation is only one week, I presume you at at Merrimack again now. If there is the slightest possibility that you are not I shall blame myself still more for not writing again last month, and using all my influence for it. And whenever you want more money it will be ready for you.  I shall be anxious to hear from you again immediately, and whether you like the school as much as last term. I must stop for I slept too late this morning and must write other letters before the mail leaves. I am afraid my remissness in writing troubled you, perhaps your father and mother, and I hardly dare ask you both to forgive me yourself and apologise for me to others. I will write again soon. Sincerely yours I.S.M.
Completed

Milo, Me. FEB 27
Paid 5
Miss Antoinette B. Putnam
Reed's Ferry N.H.
Completed

Isaac  Milo Maine  March 8 1851 Dunbarton   Milo March 8, 1851
Dear Antoinette
I wrote to you as soon as I came out of the woods, a little more than a week since; but I directed the letter to Reed's Ferry, supposing that you were still there this term of the school, and it appears that you had not received it when you wrote  Your last letter has come to hand this week. This is rather an out of the way place, and the mail now gets here but in three or four days.  I am extremely sorry that carelessness occasioned you trouble or anxiety. I was much to blame that I did not answer your letter in January, as soon as I received it and before I went away into the woods.  I did not expect to be gone so long.  Forgive me and I will try to do better in the future.  I can imagine how troubled I should be at failing to hear from you fearing that you were sick, and hardly knowing what evil to dread.  I presume that my last letter, directed to Reed's Ferry, would be forwarded to you, and you probably received it very soon after writing.
Completed

I am here at home still, and quite in a quandary. I am very anxious to obtain work in Maine: so as to be nearer home. I do not want to go out West or South, and that on many accounts.  I have had the assurance of employment on this Penobscot and Kenebec Rail Road, where I was at work in December: but that company have got into trouble, and cannot now arrange their affairs so as to begin.  They expect to build the Road, partly upon the credit of the other Roads towards Portland: who are still willing to help, but the Bangor people have got into a quarrell about it among themselves, and the wealthiest men are now trying to divide their resources to build another road.  Still they may settle their difficulties at any time, conclude to go on and build immediately, and offer me just the situation that I want.  On that account I dislike to go any where else.  Yet I can hardly bear to be entirely idle. I feel as if I was losing ground in my business all the time; nor can I afford it.  Mr Everett, whom you perhaps remember, who was with me at Goffstown, and last Summer and Fall, is now in New York State.  He has got a very good situation on the New York and Erie Rail Road. I have been
Completed

wanting to go out there; and perhaps should before this tie, if I had not constantly expected some decision about this Penobscot and Kennebec Rail Road.  Since I came out of the woods, I have turned Farmer or Wood Chopper, and have been getting up and chopping a 'Big' pile of wood.  If you should ride by the wood pile some day and see me, with my brother's old frock on, with my brown face, and hard farmer's hands, I do not think you would know me. They say however that I am one of the very best 'workers.'  Sister Lucy is still here in Milo.  We hope that her health improves slowly, but she is still feeble.  Mother's health is very good.   I shall hope to hear from you again very soon, and that you will not remember against me your anxiety at not hearing from me. I hope your father and mother are well and all. Why did you conclude not to stay at Merrimack this term? or were you going back? I had hoped that you would stay there another term, if, as I thought, you would like so to do.  Do write soon, and believe me your  Sincere I.S. Metcalf
Completed

MILO Me.  MAR 11 
PAID 5
Miss Antoinette B. Putnam
Dunbarton N.H.
Completed

Isaac New York City   April 6, 1851   Dunbarton
New York City, Sabbath April 6, 1851
Dear Antoinette   I have not heard from you for some time, but think it likely that you have written, but I have been moving about so much that your letter has had no chance to reach me.  I left Milo two weeks ago tomorrow, but did not get away from Waterville until the next Friday. I wanted much to go, if only for a day, up to New Hampshire and Dunbarton, but concluded it would not do to stop for it. I was coming right to New York that week; but learning that my old Chief Mr. Field now of the Greenfield Branch, wanted to see me at Greenfield, I took that route, and went there Saturday Montague where my cousins are is but a few miles from Greenfield, and I thought best to spend the Sabbath with them, which was quite pleasant.  Mr Field is anxious to have me upon the same Road with himself, but nearly finished there, and has not yet decided where he shall be next. By his advice, I changed my plan, and went out across the mountains upon the Line of the proposed Troy and Greenfield R.R. On this Line in the town of Florida, near North Adams, is where the great Tunnel is projected. A Tunnel 4 miles or more in length under the whole mountain, 1200 feet below the top of one ridge and 1500 feet below the other, and 800 feet
Completed

below the valley between them, through which runs a small river!  If built it will far surpass every other Rail Road work in the United States. The friends of the project are now quite confident of success. They hope to obtain a Loan of $2,000,000 from the State of Mass. If they do, a situation upon that Road is one of the strings of my bow!
The Chief Engineer who is now building the West End of the same Road, Abe Johnson, I served under upon the Vt. & Mass. R.R.  Mr. Johnson I found at Hoosick Falls N.Y. He recommended me to the Mohawk Valley R.R. and I concluded to go to Utica to see Mr. Brodhead its Chief Engineer.  Mr. Brodhead is about the finest looking Engineer I have ever seen, and I think I should really like to serve with or under him. But I found that it was not likely to be decided for two months at least whether than Road is to to be built immediately, and therefore came back to Albany, and down here yesterday. And so here I am to spend the Sabbath in this "great city," I do not know as it is great as Nineveh was, but is is certainly a great city, and great too in wickedness and wrong. How full it is of temptation and how many are ruined by its temptations. And yet how much of good it must contain As one approaches it looks almost like a 'forest of church spires, and surrounded by a 'forest of masts! The masts too in these days are pretty well mixed up with the great black steamboat chimneys.
If it continues to rain so very hard as it does now I do not think I shall get very far to church this forenoon, if indeed I try to go at all.
Completed

I do not enjoy going to Church so well in a strange place where I do not even know who is to preach. One feels somewhat solitary. By the way, what solitude there is in a great city where one is entirely unacquainted. I am never lonesome in the woods, but really I came very near it as I walked these crowded streets last morning.
Well, I was very fortunate in getting to Church this forenoon in the rain. I entered the nearest, and found it the Old  Brick Presbyterian Church, Garden Spring S.D.  The Church was really pretty well filled in spite of the rain, and I think the most devout appearing audience I ever saw in a city. And the Sermon was excellent indeed, upon Confidence in God.
This afternoon I went away "Up town," to the Church of the Puritan's Dr Cheever's, I do not know how many miles, but it is a great ways, and both places are in the middle of the City! However I got there a long time before service; Being "Up town" and Aristocratic, services do not commence till most Four. So I kept walking till then; among the rest looked in to the Magnificent Grace Church, and admired Windows, Ceilings, and Monuments. Dr Cheever preached at his Church, and was eloquent upon the Gospel Call, but I believe I did not like him or his brilliant Church quite as well as Dr Spring and his plain one.
One does not walk far in the streets here without realising that he is out of New England. I went up today by way of Chatham St. and the Bowery, And in many quarters saw the stores all open and business & every thing apparently like any day in the week. Away Up Town every thing was quiet and Sabbath like, or tolerably so, and looked like the Upper parts of Boston, only greater and richer. I came down Broadway direct, and there again the thousands
Completed

of genteel loafer and their cigars did not look like New England.
Another thing a New Englander notices in this city, or indeed any of the smaller ones I have been in in New York, (Troy, Albany, Utica, Schenectady, Hudson, the great variety of languages heard in street conversation and seen upon the signs. In some streets half the signs will be something besides English, from "Deutscdhe's Gast Haus", to "Coiffeur de Paris," &c. &c.
I made yesterday an application for a situation as Division engineer upon the Great Illinois Central Rail Road.  I shall remain here until Tuesday morning, hoping to receive an answer. If not I think I shall start that day out over the Erie R.R.
I want much to hear from you, but do not know how to get letters, as I do not know, how far I shall go, or where, or when I shall get there   Next Week, may find me in Virginia, or in almost any of the Western  States.
However I will write to you frequently, and let you know where I may be likely to get letters as soon as possible.
In the meantime my regards the family, and much love to yourself Sincerely I.S. Metcalf
Please excuse this for it is dark
Completed

Isaac  Milo Maine  April 25, 1851  Dunbarton
Milo, Maine, April 25, 1851
Dear Antoinette  I find myself once more here at Milo. I have not yet received your letter, though I learn that one arrived here not long after I went away. The folks sent it to Bangor, thinking to forward it to me, as soon as they knew where to send it. So I have just missed it:  And you may imagine am not a little uneasy: it is so long since I have heard from you. I came very near going up into New Hampshire this week to see you. But, not only had I been travelling about so much that I was getting short of money, but I was in great haste to get down here to find letters which I expected to find here awaiting me. So I came as rapidly as possible only about two days from Albany here and arrived here yesterday  afternoon.  I believe when I wrote to you I was in New York City. From there I went out over the N.Y. and Erie Rail Road, spending more than a week out on that Rail Road. It is perhaps the most magnificent Road in the county, and well worthy of considerable examination, especially from an Engineer.  Out there I found, not only Mr Everett, but also quite a number
Completed

of Massachusetts Engineers of my acquaintance, and too made the acquaintance of several others.  By invitation of Mr McRee Swift of the Superintending Engineer I formed one of a party of Engineers etc going out over an unfinished part of the Road for a first experimental trip with a Locomotive; the first Locomotive in Cattaraugus County.   I formed a considerable acquaintance with  Mr Swift and like him very much. There is a new Rail Road projected from Hartford Conn. to Fishkill New York, to connect there with the Newburg Branch of the N.Y. and Erie R.R. of which Mr Swift, who has a very high reputation, will probably have charge.  If so I have a promise of good situation upon it, which I think would suit me finely. Would you not rather be in New England?  They are projecting a great abundance of new Rail Roads in Western and Central New York; but I do not all all like the prospects of most of them. I do not wish to get upon another such Road as the N.H. Central even if I am idle a while. And I do dislike being idle I believe as much as anyone can. I am so anxious and uneasy, and almost low spirited. I want to know just what I have to do, and then I do so love to do it. I do want now some fixed situation, where I can be pleasantly established, and have a dear Antoinette constantly with me to make my home pleasant and happy and good.
Completed

From the Erie R.R. I crossed over at Elmira by way of Jefferson and the beautiful Seneca Lake to Geneva. I stopped some both in Auburn and Syracuse, where there are various Rail Roads projected.  Syracuse is a very beautiful city, and increasing very rapidly.  I stopped in Troy N.Y. and came very near remaining there., but the chance I could have there upon the Troy and Boston Road, that end of it, did not suit me, if I must agree to remain there permanently in that situation. I should like very well to get a situation upon the other end of that line when the Company get to Two Million Loan from the State of Mass. and go right on to build the Tunnel through Hoosick Mountain. I should much like to be connected with that work.  But a subordinate position on the other end I did not like, and Mr Johnson himself advised me not to stop for the place he could offer me. Every good place being already filled. Well, I am still out of business, and perhaps likely to remain so for a month or more. I have got away Down East again and believe I shall stop and be patient. I have got some new scientific works of importance  to me, upon Bridge Construction etc. and think I shall devote myself to study awhile while waiting.  Sister Lucy still remains feeble, though we hope she is gradually gaining health and strength. Brother EIliab, who has not been very well though the winter, is much better. Lucy is still here at Milo, but will probably go to Bangor next week, and Mother too.
Completed

I must tell you how I found some relatives away out in Western New York, in South Dansville Stueben Co. A Half Brother of my Mother's, who moved away there some twenty five years ago, into a place which until the N.Y. and Erie R. R. was built was perhaps more difficult of access than almost any where in the Western States. So I had never seen him or any of his family. When I finally succeeded in informing them who I was they were glad enough to see me, and I was a good deal pleased with my new found relatives, a quiet homely farmer's family with New England habits and customs well preserved in a strange land, it seemed. There was quite a pleasant family of Cousins, boys and girls, six in all. One of the girls, only nineteen years old, was married last summer, but happened to be at the old home, when I was there.  Quite a matron I can assure you.   I had a very pleasant visit there, though short. The season out in New York is quite advanced the winter wheat and grass in some places, perhaps a foot high. Last week was cold there though as well as here. Why, here there is snow and ice to be found yet in some sheltered situations, and vegetation has hardly begun, or only begun, to start.  I shall hope to hear from you very soon. It seems a great - very while, since I have heard from you. My Love & Respect to Father & Mother, etc.  Most Sincerely I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Isaac  May 22 1851  Dunbarton
Milo, ME. May 11, 1851
Dear Antoinette,  It is sabbath afternoon, and the most beautiful of May weather. I could almost fancy myself in Italy or Greece as I look from my window upon the mellow hase of the atmosphere, and the richness of the summer clouds that lie so still in the western sky.  I have not been at Meeting today - for there was none to attend.  I went to Sabbath School though, or rather to assist in organising the Sabbath School for the season, which was fairly accomplished in due form, and with full prospect of interest and good. I think the Sabbath School will be very large in proportion to the whole attendance at Meetings.  There seems a much more hopeful prospect of benefitting the young here than the older, and I am not sure that Ministers might not properly and profitably devote more of their attentions and effort to the children.  I heard one Minister, (Rev Mr. Hayes of Frankfort Me.) say last winter that he had for some years systematically devoted one half of his efforts, both in the pulpit and out, to the juvenile portions of his parish, and his only doubt was whether he should not a still larger portion.  The people here expected to have preaching now all, or about all, of the time; A Free Will Baptist 'Elder" once a month, a Calvinist Baptist the same, and Congregationalist half the Sabbaths; all in the same house, - or Hall.  The Meetings are held in Sons of Temperance Hall.
Completed

The Congregationalist Minister is a young man from New Hampshire, Mr Partridge of Petersboro' I believe.  He preaches half of the time in this, and half in the adjoining towns of Sebee, Half of his salary is paid by the Maine Missionary Society, one quarter by people of each town.  Mr P. is a very young man, and I should judge of very defective education. Still he seems to be very well liked here, and I hope will be very useful. He is lately married. One thing is perhaps favorable now in Milo; the full harmony and apparent union between the different denominations, shown in every thing.  The S.P. Superintendent is a Baptist, the Teachers of the three denominations indiscriminately.  Saturday May 17  I commenced this letter nearly a week since, but remembering that you were probably not a home, and would not get it if I sent it then, I have laid it by.  I suppose you have been for a week or two past in Massachusetts visiting your relatives, and, I hope and presume, enjoying yourself finely.  I shall expect to hear, by your next letter of a very agreeable visit.  Sometime, we will expect, it Providence permit, to visit some of our uncles and cousins, yours and mine, together, and enjoy it nicely.  I have been enjoying myself since I last wrote you; perhaps spending my time more pleasantly than profitably, as far as any pecuniary profit at least is concerned.  I have generally read and studied a part, nearly a half, of every day, and the rest of the time have been at work on the Farm.  I do love and enjoy farming and farm works.  I believe about the best of any employment. I like to take right hold of the work, and the hardest of it, and work all the
Completed

time, and though I have practised it so little since I was a boy, I find that I can do most things about as well, and endure as much fatigue as any of the farmers. I do not know but I had better propose to my brother to pay me the same wages he does a hired man.  I believe I have done about as much work while I have been here.  To give you the detail of my avocations would be to go through the while list of Farmer's "Spring Work".  I sometimes think that nature must have intended me for a Farmer, and really if I were able to do it as I would like, I might sometime give up other occupations and devote myself to that.  Had I better go out West and make a farm of some beautiful prairie!  You hope that I will not be "low spirited". I believe I am not very apt to suffer much in that way.  I never had what people call "the blues" and which some really suffer so much from.  I think I rather enjoy the present constitutionally, and instead of looking upon the dark side of the future, am perhaps too much inclined not to think of it at all!  The Season here I think has been rather backward. It is perhaps little no farther advanced here now than I saw it in Southern New York a month since, thought the weather is now warmer here. Only the earliest trees are in full leaf now, Poplars, White Birch etc. Maples, Elms, Larches, and Apple trees are but just beginning to open their leaves.  Among my other jobs, I have been transplanting trees here, some fruit trees, and some forest trees. Flowers I believe are not very abundant here this Spring,
Completed

or, at least I have seen only the most common and familiar varieties. Those however are old and long loved favorites, now some of them doubly dear, though calling up emotions of sadness, associated as they are with the memory of my dear Brother, who loved them so well.  I do not know as I ever acknowledged the receipt of your Father's Anti Fugitive Slave Law Sermon. I was very much pleased with it as were many others who have read it here.  I guess there has never been much excitement here upon the subject; but would be if there were any attempt to execute the law.  I found it when travelling, a prominent subject of conversation every where, a topic not easily exhausted.  I think I shall leave here now within a few days. I am getting impatient at waiting so long. I seem to be too far away here. will go out into the world, to see what is going on!  I think I shall go to Hartford next week, perhaps to New York.  If I do not get too busy, I will hope to get to Dunbarton in a week or two.  It seems a good while since I saw you. I will write again as soon as I have any place to write from, -or before. I may not leave Bangor, till after 26th Inst.   My love and respect to Father & Mother, and much love to yourself Sincerely I.S. Metcalf
Milo May 20th  Has not this letter been long in the writing
Completed

Isaac   Chicago Illinois    June 15 1851  Dunbarton
Chicago, Illinois, June 13, 1851
Dear Antoinette  It seems a great while since I heard from you, or indeed since I last wrote to you.  I have been waiting and waiting, and hoping and expecting that I should soon have something more definite to write.  But I will delay it no longer, even though I lack one of the dearest incentives to writing - the expectation of an immediate answer.  How I have wandered about since I last wrote to you.  I must give you the history of my journeyings I believe - If I can remember it.  I came to Bangor, very soon after I wrote to you and remained there a few days. Tuesday May 27 I journeyed from Bangor to Boston by Stage Coach, and Rail Way. Wednesday forenoon I spent in Boston in some business, procuring some Grave Stones etc. In the afternoon I went to Greenfield Mass. The next day was very rainy and I remained there all day, or rather at Montague, where my Cousins live.  Friday May 30, I went to Hartford Conn.,  but very soon found that there was very little prospect that any thing of consequence would be done upon the Hartford and Fishkill Road for some time, perhaps not even this season.  So I was entirely out there. If I had immediately returned to Springfield and gone on the Albany at once. I might have been better off
Completed

But I wanted to see a little more of Hartford, ad concluded to remain, and so go right on to New York City, and spend the Sabbath there. I went over to Brooklyn to Meeting and though I did not hear the preacher I was expecting, I was very much pleased. It was Rev A.L. Stone of Boston who it appeared had exchanged with Dr Storry of Brooklyn. I had been wishing to hear Mr Stone; and his eloquence was indeed all I could have expected. I thing his sermons were about the most elegant I ever heard. The thought was excellent, while the expression was beautiful and polished to the highest degree.  Going up to Albany on Monday, I found that if I had been there only a day or two sooner I might have had a good situation, probably just about what I should want, upon the Albany and Susquehanna R.R Albany to Binghampton.  Mr. Edward C. Delavan, the celebrated Temperance man, is the President of the Company, and the principal man.   I began to think myself unlucky, but went on to Utica, remaining there Tuesday June 3.  When I was there before I had had about the promise of a situation upon the Mohawk Valley R.R. Utica to Schenectady, if I would wait until June.  But now it appeared that the Company had become involved in an intrigue with the Old Corporation; were quite likely even to sell out, and do nothing.  At any rate there would be nothing done for a month or two.  So I went on.  I stopped at Canadaigua, at Rochester, at Batavia, Attica, and Buffalo; but found no business for me.  Perhaps I could have done better if I had been there a month
Completed

or two sooner. There is a great deal doing in RailRoads in Western New York; a great many new projects. But I am unacquainted there. Nobody knows me.  If I could have been out there for a year or two past so as to be known in almost any capacity. I think I might this Spring have been pretty well situated, perhaps a Chief Engineer on some road. I really have the vanity to believe that there are some not truly better qualified than myself, who are now receiving two or three thousand dollars a year. I spent the Sabbath, June 8th, at Westfield N.Y. with my sister Anne, who I believe I have told you is since Jan. last year a Teacher in Westfield Academy. I enjoyed a day or two in Westfield very much. Westfield is a beautiful place; Mr. Rumsey's where my sister boards is a very pleasant family.  I really felt almost at home at once. Mr Tinker, the Presbyterian Minister at Westfield, formerly I think a Missionary at Sandwich Islands, is an excellent preacher, one of the best.  Monday 9th, was so windy that the Steamboats could not call in at Westfield or Barcelona. So I rode to Erie Penn. by Stage Coach unclear the night, ad remained there one day.  Then at Cleaveland, Ohio, one day; and at Detroit, Michigan, and today have safely arrived at Chicago Illinois.  One can get about pretty fast nowadays, even and stop a while occasionally.  The Michigan Central R.R. across the whole state from Detroit to New Buffalo or Michigan City, in ten or twelve hours, saves considerable time above a steamboat passage around the Lakes.  I should think however that the steamboat passage must be extremely pleasant in good weather.  By some time next year it is expected that
Completed

there will be a continuous RailRoad Route completed and running all the way from Buffalo to Chicago, and perhaps even to Galena.  It will certainly be quite a convenience to travellers in the winter season.  It might not much interest you, if I had time and room to write you all my observations, reflections, and memoranda upon all the towns, cities, places, and routes I have visited many of them you know something about.  I have taken time to look at most a little at least.  Canadaigua, Westfield, and Cleaveland  I think are about the handsomest places I ever saw.  Rochester, Buffalo, and Chicago the most active and prosperous.  I think I shall go from here to Springfield next.  Perhaps remain here over the Sabbath though. It is thought now that I can have employment upon this Great Illinois Central R.R. that is to be; the whole length of the State, from Cairo on the Mississippi River, diverging somewhere to two Northern Termini, Chicago, and Galena.  It is a great project, but Boston and New York Capitalists have undertaken it with the half of the large grants of land from government, and it is doubtless to be built as fast as possible.  I intend to meet Col. Mason, who has been appointed Chief Engineer of the whole, at Springfield Illinois, sometime next week, last of the week probably he is to be there.  Farther than that I can tell nothing what I shall do. But I will write to you again as soon as any thing is decided.  I shall go to LaSalle by Canal, then by Steamboat to Naples, and RailRoad to Springfield, I think.  This is really a long letter, and it seems as if I had hardly begun to write anything. How I do want to hear from you as well as from Maine. I have not heard a word since I started, and I am anxious all the time about Lucy's health.  It is 11 and I slept but little last night, I must stop. This letter will not hold half the love I want to send to you. I must send that by Telegraph; same to Father, Mother, brother, sisters.  Sincerely, I.S.
Completed

Isaac  Springfield  Illinois
June 21  1837
Springfield Illinois, Sat. Eve. June 21. 1837.
Dunbarton
Dear Antoinette
What will you think to hear that besides being away in this land, I am here away from every body, with no business, and out of money, in the midst, not of Fever & Ague merely, but of both Cholera & Small Pox! My, I could make out quite a strong case!  And "founded on fact" too!
However, I guess the case is in reality not quite so bad. I came here, as I think I wrote to you I should, to meet Col R.B. Mason, who was to be here, the 20th. & 21st, incl.  The great freshet and roads broken up, have prevented his getting here, and we hear this evening that he has taken another route and gone back to Chicago. Thus leaving me in the lurch.
However, I have met here with another gentleman connected with the road, who is pretty fully acquainted with its affairs, and knows where I am most needed. He wishes me to proceed at once to the Southern Division, and I think I will on Monday.  I had preferred to remain somewhere toward the Northern part of the state, thinking that would be more healthy; but it seems their lines are running all back on the high grounds, away from the Marshes, and it may really be the healthiest part of the route. Cairo is very low & unhealthy, and now all under water, but their Head quarters are to be at Caledonia, 15 miles above, and they do not go near Cairo, at present.
Completed

I had quite a tiresome journey from Chicago here, four days; 100 Miles by Canal, 200 Miles by Steamboat on the Illinois River, and 60 Miles by Railway.
The Flood on the Illinois River is immense. The River Much of the way appears to be boundless; on the wooded banks the trees are to be seen, but no land. And the Villages, or Cities they call them here, along the banks are almost entirely submerged.  Frequently the Steamboat landings are made to the second story of Warehouses and in some cases the second floor even has been exceeded by the water.  I never saw any thing like it. As Naples we left the Steamboat for the second floor of the Depot Warehouse; Boats instead of Carriages were waiting to convey passengers up town to the Hotels, where we dined upon a floating floor, the water being considerably into the house, and four or five feet deep around it. After dinner we were carried in boats perhaps quarter of a mile farther to where the cars stood, above the Village.
I should think they might have most any diseases at Natchez! And the Cholera does prevail there I understand and the Small Pox too, and brought from there, there have been a few cases at Springfield.
I found some acquaintances here, families from Maine named Greenleaf.  One is a Conductor upon this R. Road, and took the Varaoloid (sic its a form of smallpox) at Naples, and communicated it to his family. His wife, formerly Martha Lee of Milo, and a very beautiful woman, had it severely, and is like to be badly marked. She has but lately recovered.
Completed

The Cholera I do not feel at all afraid of. It appears to be confined entirely to the intemperate, dissipated and suffering. I presume that with proper prudence and attention, there is no sort of danger for a person of correct habits.  Noticing the habits of people here, I have wondered they did not most all die of Cholera or something else.
Sabbath Afternoon
This forenoon at the First Presbyterian Church I heard I think quite a character; Rev Dr Smith, an old Scotshman, a very big man very awkward & slovenly in his appearance, strongly nasal in his pronunciation; but, I judge, very extensively educated {I can think of no better term} a great logician and reasoner, considerably eloquent and with as much power, depth and unclear of voice as I ever heard. He is certainly a great preacher! I think very few men could be more effective as a field preacher. His sermon this forenoon was an excellent one, about an hour long, of close argument, without notes, and by no means dull.
They have no afternoon service in the churches here. The morning service is at 10 1/2 A.M. the other at 7 1/2 P.M.
I believe I must stop, and write a little to the folks in Maine, just to let them know I am going to St. Louis tomorrow, thence by Steamboat to Cairo and Caledonia.  I believe I shall go by Stage Coach to Alton Ill. then over to St. Louis, and take one of the Ohio River Boats.
Yours Sincerely
I.L.
Completed

Mis Antoinette B. Putnam
Dunbarton
New Hampshire 
Springfield  JUN 23
PAID  10
Completed

Isaac  Chester Illinois
June 29 1857
Dunbarton
Chester Illinois, Sabbath Eve. June 29. 1857
Dear Antoinette
I believe I must spend a little while this evening in writing to you. I have not been at Church t all today. It has been a very rainy day. The Illinois black mud is very deep. The Church is a long way off, and at the top of a very high bluff.  Therefore being assured by the natives that there would be no meeting I did not undertake to go up. I hear since however that there was a meeting in the A.M.and ten persons present, but this afternoon the minister did not attempt to go.  He is an old school Presbyterian, formerly of Louisville Ky.
So I have been in my room all day, reading some, and I must confess, sleeping some.  I was happy to find here in this little Tavern as indeed I have frequently in the West, the Am. unclear Soc. Evan. Fam. Library Series, in which one can always find good reading.
I have written a letter to my Mother this afternoon, and have been thinking a good deal of way Down East, of Mother, Brothers and Sisters at Milo & Bangor, and of your dear self.
You can hardly imagine how anxious I am becoming to hear from you all, or what an age it seems since I have heard.
Only to think what a long time it has been, Almost five weeks since I left Bangor, and have not heard from there since, and longer still since I heard from you!
I believe I wrote to you last from Springfield about a week ago. From Springfield I went to Alton by Stage Coach Oh what a ride across those prairies, sometimes the horizon as unlimited as on the broad ocean, sometimes most beautiful groves of timber; and then the prairie flowers.  But I cannot describe it; and you have seen the Prairies for yourself. I did not stop at Alton. I have had a sort of dislike for Alton and have considered it almost as under a curse, since the death of Lovejoy there.  I went to St. Louis and stopped there one day, and was surprised at its wealth, business & prosperity. From St. Louis I went around to Cairo & to Caledonia on the Ohio River, where I remained one day, and then came around here. My destination is back in Perry County some fifty miles
Completed

perhaps East of here. I do not know but more, it is along the Eastern Edge of the County.  I wanted to get there Saturday night, but found myself unable.
My Contract with the Illinois Central R.R. Co. is only conditional at present.  I have not bound myself to remain, as they could not just now offer me such a situation as I want.  But in the Meantime I have agreed to go to work, hoping if I like, and the Country suits me, to have before long the offer of a proper situation.  If not, I shall not remain.
With my present position my pay is only $65.00 per Month, and expenses paid. As I expect, it will be $90. or 100 & expenses. It is said to be a very healthy region where I am going. Some say the most healthy part of the whole State, but I know nothing how I shall like it as yet. If I do not like, or the Climate does not agree with me, I shall not remain, that is certain.
I suppose that my Post Office Address will be:
Mount Hawkins, Perry Co. Ill.
but I guess that I will not mail this letter until I get out there and know more definitely what my place is to be.
July 6.
This part of a letter was written about a week ago, and I am only sorry it was not sent along then, as I might then in that case be expecting an answer now or very soon.
I shall not be likely to write much more, as my conveniences for such things are by no means extensive and the sun begins to shine much too near my Bench.
Hoping to hear very soon, & as soon as possible that you and yours are well and happy, I remain
Yours most sincerely
I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Isaac           Jackson Co. Illinois
July 6 1851
Dunbarton              Sabbath Afternoon July 6 1851 
I cannot give the name of this place, for I doubt if it has one.
It is somewhere in Jackson Co. Ill; about 10 miles east? of Murphresboro?
place itself is simply the residence of an old Pennsylvania Dutch farmer
away in the woods unclear little way from every body and every where.

   I wish you could see the house. It is a log house, or rather two log houses 

a dozen feet apart, one room each with a roof over the space between
thus making a third room with the ends all open.  This third middle room
is, at this season at least, is the one principally used as a sitting and eating room
and is really very comfortable.

    The family here I should think must be near a dozen, and our party 

make about as many more! Only three rooms you remember!
This is said to be one of the best stopping places in this region.
However there is a good airy barn on the premises, and beside the porch
between the two rooms is a good sleeping place for me, and as they 
give me my choice, I get along tolerably well. 
My worst trouble with this country is the lack of good water. The
people here make this the reason for drinking immoderately of Coffee
and also of ardent spirits. In fact, I have been remonstrated with very seriously
upon this unclear and unclear that the only way was to 
dilute the water of the Country with a little Brandy or as the Dutch do with Whiskey
My persistence in taking it pure appears very strange?to them I suppose.
There I unclear  have even seen Children soaking their bread in Whiskey
As others would in milk.

Last Sabbath I did not go to Church. Today I have been sorry 
I did not try harder last Sabbath as I am here in a still more 
as I am here in a still more uncomfortable place
and no possibility, as I can find, of getting unclear any time
Completed

of a meeting. My only resource is the shady side of the Barn, where, upon a work bench, I have my books & paper spread before me and I am really tolerably contented. It is a very warm day and the sun shines some but the Barn is by no means close, the logs of which it is composed touching each other only at the corners, and the cool breeze draws through finely.

 I suppose you, as well as my Mother, may be a little anxious about my health; but I do not feel at all apprehensive about it; and beside am under no obligations to remain, and shall leave a once if I find the Climate affects me.   I have purposely delayed, or refrained from entering into any permanent arrangements, upon those very grounds.

 I left Chester Monday last, arriving that night at the place where our Head quarters is, or is to be, Mount Hawkins Perry Co.  Or rather that is the name of the nearest Post Office.  The Place is "Locust Hill"   The next day arrived here, or at our starting point upon the North bank of Muddy river, and have now been at work four days, pleasantly and successfully.

 I ought to have sent this letter sooner, as I am getting extremely anxious to hear from you: but thought I would wait until I could get upon the ground.  When I got here I found I knew no more than before: but have been very much busy in getting business started and have had no opportunity to send to the Post Office.  How long it is since I have heard from you!  And the days will seem long now till I can get a letter from you.
 
  You will write as soon as you get this will you not, and it will be safer to direct to 'Care of B. G. Roots Esq' Mt. Hawkins Perry Co. Ill.

  If I do not make satisfactory permanent arrangements here, before a long time, you may expect to see me again in New Hampshire.
Completed

unclear
Aug 2 1837
Mr. Hawkins, Perry Co. unclear Aug. 2. 1837
Dear Antoinette
Your kind & excellent letter was received yesterday, and with very great pleasure I assure you. It had been so long since I heard from you; and I was getting very impatient, and anxious. And I have not yet heard from home, Mother, Brother, or Sister. Letters had a little farther to go there you know than to you which would make the answers? one or two days later, but I shall now expect them next mail at any rate.
I am very much obliged to you for writing immediately on the receipt of my letter. A single day when me is waiting is a good while. I should have written the day I received yours, but that there is no mail until Monday.
As you may imagine, I have by this time had considerable experience of Life among the Suckers. I have certainly learned a good many new things. We have made a survey 30? miles through Southern Illinois. I can tell you so you can trace our course on the map. If on your maps the Base Lines & Meridians of the W.I.? Government Land Surveys are laid down, it is easily unclear. We commenced where the "Third Principal Meridian", {which is nearly the Meridian of Cairo & Vandalia} crosses Big Muddy River in Jackson County, and run Motherly through Jackson Perry & Washington Counties to the "Base Line" which is thirty of forty miles south of Vandalia. The whole distance, eastern people would think almost uninhabited; they call it here prolly well settled, which means simply that there is an occasional Farm, say from one to twelve miles apart I think that in the fifty miles we did pass within ten miles
Completed

postmark:
Jonesborough ILL
Nov 7
Miss Antoinette B. Putnam
Dunbarton  N.H.
Completed

Isaac   Jonesboro Union Co ILL
Dec 1 1851
Jonesboro Union Co. Illinois
Sabbath, Nov. 30. 1851

 Dear Antoinette   Your letter of November eleventh reached me on the twenty sixth, making the journey in considerable less than the usual time, and as usual gladdening my heart not a little. The same evening, by the same Mail, came also letters from Bangor, Brothers and Sisters. A very comfortable preparation for Thanksgiving to be sure.  Yet, I think, if I had not been unusually or at least extremely busy, I should have been on that day lonesome, or almost homesick. Thanksgiving is not at all observed here; in fact no one seemed to remember the day; and it is a day when, you know, a New Englander especially thinks of home and its surroundings, of relatives and friends, and more than ever longs to be with them.
